title: Biopolitics,” based on Michel Foucault’s “biopower,” has been used in many disciplines to describe practices of protecting and regulating life. Foucault’s notion of biopower and elaborations of it by Giorgio Agamben, Michael Hardt, and Antonio Negri argue that a sovereign state’s ultimate power is to govern the lives of its population through the regulation of medical meaning, expertise, and intervention. I evoke biopolitics loosely to highlight the relationship between biological, social, and political structures. I concentrate on the development of body beliefs by both professionals and amateurs. Of this vast literature, I particularly consulted Paul Rabinow and Nikolas Rose, “Biopower Today
